comments.commentBody: The problem is that the cat is out of the bag.  N Korea has demonstrated Nuclear capability and a growing delivery systems that will eventually be capable of reaching the continental US.  N Korea has enough warheads and fissionable materials, a hard to target delivery system, advantages of weather/cloud cover to be a serious threat.  While the US has an accuracy and reliability requirements before deployment, the fact that N Korea either through unreliable engineering or through foreign intervention has unreliable systems is not a deterrent to deployment.  As the old saying goes, "close only counts in horseshoes and atom bombs".   Part of the challenge is Trumps initial anti-Chinese posture when the ultimate solution will likely require their cooperation.

Also part of the challenge is that his initial anti-Chinese posture was to manipulate the Chinese into issuing him the patents to his name, which he had been attempting to secure for many years. He succeeded. His attention is chronically diverted, rather than fully focused on the country.

You're projecting, MD. You just inject "you might get quite angry! Don't try to control! Men aren't picky!"

From 'what you've seen', you are applying your own experiences onto Amy. You'll be most satisfied if Jason stumbles after Amy's death! Ha!

It's really wrong to insert doubt and self-judgement into someone's well-considered decisions. I'll bet you're a joy to converse with!

Why would you say this? If it left you feeling dead,maybe it's because you have never experienced a love like hers. If you thought it was anything but what it is meant to be,a love letter to her husband,why bother saying anything negative?

Hopefully our boy-President will hear by, I mean hearby, I mean hereby make the most intelligent choice among the options about how to proceed.  Right now he is texting about The Apprentice from Mar A Lago (really, he is), probably in his bathrobe, but I'm sure he will get to this urgent matter soon.

OK, look, I am certainly no supporter of President Trump, but right now, he's the only President we have (possibly other than Bannon ).

Claiming he is ignoring urgent matters while tweeting ephemera in his bathrobe is the same as the claim above that President Obama spent his time yammering about climate change instead of concentrating on serious issues.

You don't know, you can't know, and this kind of complaining, though it may feel good for a moment does nobody any good and contributes to the impression of an unfocused, fracturing, weakened America...

When, President for Life Kim, the truth is everyone here is United in disliking you and your murdering government, make no mistake.
A gift of love and eternity.

Another problem that Trump neither has the capacity or the desire to deal with.

After all, he can't build luxury hotels there, nor can his daughter sell her stinking perfume.
Hey, he will say "well, um, I think (re: hope) our generals will know what to do".

You believe in States' Rights?

Then stop sending ICE agents to deport valued members of our communities and to beak up our families.

Stop pushing national gun rules that would force careful states to ignore unhinged people from states with weak permitting who want to carry weapons in our streets

History shows that Republicans fight for "States Rights" for States that want to take away the rights of citizens to vote; or for States where Republcans let ALEC and selfish donors block protections for air and water.

As most sensible readers have already pointed out, it is not about the meetings but the evasion. The Republicans chose to impeach President Clinton because he wanted to keep his personal life private. This is not about privacy but public records.

As an aside, with so much talk about the Russian ambassador, have people thought about what might Putin do?
Sorry, but why is this kind of info not classified and being published in the NYT? This is the kind of info that should be kept under wraps that the public really doesn't need to know.

On the contrary, I believe everyone on the planet should know, if they haven't already conjured up the potential situation in their own mind to begin with.

The first time I saw Kim parading missiles like the USSR used to do on May Day I was made aware of the fact it was never a question of if, but when.
What exactly is news here?  It's a nice summing up of what any thinking person should already have known.
Imagine if you will that a democrat trusts his government so much that he volunteers to go obliviously to hell, never to know why. Is there a place in democracy for that view? One disagrees, sir.

Who died and made the Times arbiter of "whether we can counter North Korea's nuclear threat"? Please stop with the editorializing headlines. In fact, keep the editorials in the opinion section, will you? Times editors have come to feel they are just as good at policymaking as government. Maybe with the government we have now, but not with a real government.
given this administration probably better

I thought I submitted this a few hours ago, but maybe not?

Two themeless in a row that I really enjoyed. I loved almost all of those long entries. Mary Lou suggests there would be different demographics for the successful solve of 3D and 53A but hopes the crosses would make them possible. In fact I could have had 14 letters in 3D and still not known, so did reluctantly look that up. It was a delight to see SHIRLEY CHISHOLM as others have said.

I caught on to all the misdirectional clues, my favourite being the curling clue. I seem to remember Deb saying that she had become a fan of that sport a while back.

Many thanks, Mary Lou, for a really fun Saturday puzzle.
I am not often speechless. I am now. My heart is heavy yet soaring at the same time.

Dear Fellow Americans,

If you're going to do something, do it right, or don't bother!!!!

Holy moly..and this story on the heels of Trumps early am tirade about Obama wire tapping...What kind of perilous, parallel universe are we living in?!
How on earth can we trust an even keeled hand to lead us through this nuclear mine field with N. Korea with a deranged commander in chief?
gulp.. the timing is chilling.
bunker digging party anyone?
Duck and cover...once again...
Thanks for a depth of reporting that virtually no other entity could provide.

So Obama sat in the White House for eight years yapping about global warming all the while Kin Hong-un was busy working away, unfettered, on nuclear missile systems that were capable of annihilating most it.  Nice!
Yeah. Obama took his eye off the ball when he decided to focus on Kim Jong-un instead of the real brains in the North, Kin Hong-un.

Obama ultimately pressed the Pentagon and intelligence agencies to pull out all the stops, which officials took as encouragement to reach for untested technologies.

The North’s missiles soon began to fail at a remarkable pace

I guess you didn't read the article. Obama and the US military did take actions to slow the development of the North Korean nuclear missile program. The point the article makes however is that there are limited options short of a preemptive risky US military strike or invasion that could stop the North Korean progress to reach their goal . Such a military action would probably cause retaliation by China who by the way do have lots of nuclear ICBM's that would strike the US and as the article points out the US anti missile system costing $300 BILLION will not protect us.
Trump is inheriting this situation and will now learn that boastful statements like "it won't happen" and idle threats of military strikes you suggest should be employed are silly, harmful and don't do anything to manage or solve the problem.

Amy, I completely understand. I was diagnosed wish the same thing ten years ago. Stage 3C. I'm still here. I've had one remission in 2014. I'm great, unless i"m dead. The reality is I live from 3mo check up to 3mo. My CA125 is very "predictive." I asked my doctor the last time why have I done so well. He said some women respond really well to treatment and it can be almost a chronic condition. He thinks I'm one. Who knows. Maybe you will be, too. So don't give up.
My husband is and has been the most amazing partner in this saga. The first time I had a list of women who would have been great partners when I'm gone. Only because before me (30 years ago at that time) I thought his taste in women left a lot to be desired. After I finished treatment, we left NY to move to a slower paced university town. Such a great move. When I told him about the list, he thought it was funny, but really didn't appreciate my candidates.
But now, ten years later, I find myself trying to organize things so my husband can jump in and seamlessly handle the things I do. I'm the money manager. And, I've organized as much as I can so that he'll be OK when I'm gone. This is just what you do for someone you love beyond measure.

Congrats that you have survived such a devastating diagnosis and prognosis. To tell  another person who doesn't share your fortune to "never give up" may seem encouraging, but those who have faced the demon cancer and are moving in from us need more than cheerleading. They need to hear that it's OK, that they will be remembered and honored, not for the length of time they fought cancer but for how they lived in spite of it.

After reading this article twice, I have to comment on such a loving and honest approach to life and death that we will all endure.

When my mother realized that her cancer was not going to go away, I truly believe that she started a concerted effort, somewhat in the manner of Amy Rosenthal, to ensure my father's continued happiness.

You see, my parents had been married for 57 years, and had each left their parents home for the first time (except for my dads fun filled two years in the Ardenne forest of WWII).

So as the disease wore on, my mother taught my father how to manage a checkbook, where all the financial paperwork was, how to shop for groceries, and how to cook. She showed him how to take care of their beloved cat, a dear feline that would help my father through some of the darkest days after my mother passed. Most importantly, although I have nothing to prove it, I truly believe that my mother encouraged my father to not stay alone and to be open to new people in his life. My sister, Julie, and I cared for my father after my mother passed, and his close circle of friends provided wonderful support, but he was alone in his heart. Lightning struck for a second time though, and he met a wonderful woman, who is now his wife.

Thank you Amy for sharing your life, your love for your husband, and thoughts on how to live a better life.

The story about your parents is beautiful, particularly how "their beloved cat" helped your father cope with your mother's passing.  As a cat person, I don't know what I would do without the love of my felines in good and bad times.
Thoughts on a wonderful marriage but really it is about a woman who saw the softer side of life. Chicago and the world will miss you

My darling friend, who has survived breast cancer, said smack in the middle of her debilitating and frightening treatment "I know how love abounds."  It is a gift and blessing to see through all the "blech" and know that, articulate that, and share that.  It makes us all more mindful of the importance of giving and receiving love. Love is reflected in love.
This was so heartwarming to read!

You are right about "feminist hackles." The most "liked" comment on this article managed to conclude that the husband was only worthwhile because she, the wife, had made him so.  Think about that, without the woman, the husband wouldn't be worthwhile.  Proof that sexism only works when wielded by women.

Dear Allison, As a writer I know what it took for you to write that essay, the price you had to pay.
It's a masterpiece of elequence and brevity.
Thank you for sharing your story with the world.
It's a miracle you and your husband found one another.
Time to believe in miracles again.
Prayers sent up in your name.
Never (even after three tries and others in between) have I met anyone close to what you describe....life has been lonely ....
Believe.
AH, your comment in itself is beautiful, and has touched me.  I'll be thinking of both you and AKR.
